abstracts.cdata!:
Land acquisition for the project does
            not result in an increased number of project affected
            persons (PAFs) losing land which is less than the level
            considered the minimum economic landholding (MEL), the
            threshold level for those considered to be the most
            vulnerable. However, a large number of PAFs having land that
            is less than MEL have also lost land, and these families
            will require economic rehabilitation for restoration of
            their income. Those PAFs suffering loss of agricultural
            income are not made vulnerable because their income levels
            are above poverty level. Three defunct irrigation wells, and
            one farmhouse with a small temple are the only private
            structures and utilities affected; and compensation has been
            paid where required and the temple reconstructed. A
            community cattle drinking water trough and a marginal part
            of the village water tank will be affected, and the proposed
            bypass will also sever two of the village cart tracks. The
            list of commercial squatters will be updated and these
            persons considered as PAFs. The right-of-way (ROW) clearance
            will render squatters homeless, necessitating relocation.
            The community structures and utilities that need to be
            relocated as part of ROW clearance includes shifting of 16
            temples, five roadside drinking water posts, three toilet
            blocks and 15 bus stops.
